message_1:
In a Battle of the Sexes game, a husband and wife are deciding between two activities: going to a baseball game and going to the ballet. The husband prefers the baseball game, while the wife prefers the ballet. If they both go to the same activity, they will each receive a payoff of 1. If they go to different activities, they each receive a payoff of 0.

Suppose the husband and wife are playing this game repeatedly, and they adopt the following strategy: they start by going to the activity that they prefer. If they both choose the same activity, they continue to choose that activity. If they choose different activities, the husband switches to the wife's preferred activity in the next round.

If the game is played for an infinite number of rounds, what is the payoff for each player?

In the first round, if both the husband and wife choose their preferred activity (baseball for the husband and ballet for the wife), they will end up at different activities and receive a payoff of 0 for that round. In the next round, the husband will switch to the wife's preferred activity (ballet), and they will both receive a payoff of 1 for that round. From this point on, they will continue to choose ballet and receive a payoff of 1 in each round.

2. In the first round, if both the husband and wife choose the same activity (either baseball or ballet), they will receive a payoff of 1 for that round. Since they both chose the same activity, they will continue to choose that activity in the following rounds and receive a payoff of 1 in each round.

In both scenarios, after the first round, the husband and wife will continue to choose the same activity (ballet) and receive a payoff of 1 in each round. Since the game is played for an infinite number of rounds, we can calculate the average payoff for each player by considering the payoffs from the second round onwards.
